name: Afghanistan
currentCrisisSummary:
Since the US withdrawal and the Taliban takeover in August 2021, Afghanistan has descended into a deep and protracted humanitarian emergency. Millions face acute food insecurity and malnutrition, public services have largely collapsed, and the economy has been crippled by the freezing of central bank assets and broad financial restrictions that isolate the country from the global economy.

These policies â€” including the effective freezing of roughly $7 billion of sovereign reserves abroad â€” and a regime of sanctions and de-facto financial exclusion have drastically reduced state capacity and access to imports, with acute consequences for health, food, shelter and employment. The situation reverses fragile development gains that were dependent on external financing and has produced mass displacement, rising poverty, and heightened vulnerability for women, girls and minorities who now face systematic restrictions and exclusion.

The humanitarian emergency is not only the result of internal political change but is also sustained by international economic and geopolitical choices: Western governments' asset freezes, conditionalities and wide sanctions regimes have had direct, measurable effects on livelihoods and public services. The immediate needs are immense, and the country requires large-scale, sustained humanitarian support that is accountable to Afghan civil society and led by Afghan organisations where possible.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Britain & Russian Empire (19th c. - 1919), USSR (1979-1989), US (2001-2021)
imperialRoot.legacy:
Afghanistan's contemporary fragility is embedded in a long history of foreign intervention. In the 19th century the 'Great Game' between the British and Russian empires reshaped frontier politics and weakened indigenous centres of authority. Soviet intervention (1979-1989) and the Cold War proxy struggles that preceded it precipitated decades of violent conflict and state collapse. The US intervention after 2001 created a hollow, aid-dependent rentier state. This nation-building project was fundamentally neoliberal, prioritising privatisation, outsourcing basic services to a vast network of foreign contractors and NGOs, and imposing a market-based model that fuelled systemic corruption and was unsustainable without massive external financing.

Each major intervention reshaped Afghan social, economic and political institutions, often entrenching dependency, fragmenting local governance and amplifying violent non-state actors. The repeated external remaking of Afghanistan has therefore been a structural driver of instability and humanitarian vulnerability.

historicalContext.theGraveyardOfEmpiresMyth: The phrase 'graveyard of empires' is a trope that individualises failure and obscures the central role of sustained foreign interference. Successive imperial and great-power campaigns sought to reorder Afghan society and state institutions to serve external strategic aims â€” a process that frequently undermined local political autonomy and social cohesion. Rather than an inherent incapacity, much of Afghanistan's instability must be read as the product of repeated external interventions and extractive geopolitical competition.
historicalContext.theOpiumEconomyAndTheWarOnDrugs: The 20-year international presence operated alongside a massive opium economy. Western-led counter-narcotics strategies, framed as a 'war on drugs', consistently failed and had perverse effects: they criminalised impoverished farmers who lacked alternative livelihoods, enriched corrupt officials and warlords involved in trafficking, and functioned as another misguided external policy that destabilised rural society while ignoring the root causes of poppy cultivation.
historicalContext.economicPressureAndSanctions:
After August 2021 international financial measures â€” notably the freezing of roughly $7 billion in central bank reserves held overseas and restrictions on formal banking relations â€” have constrained Afghanistan's ability to import, pay salaries and deliver public services. Multilateral and unilateral sanctions, plus restrictive de-risking by international banks and donors' conditionalities, have contributed to economic contraction, spiralling unemployment, and a sharp deterioration in living standards. Many analysts and humanitarian actors argue that these measures, as they have been applied, function as forms of economic coercion that disproportionately punish civilians and limit humanitarian space.

These pressures have compounded the impacts of climate shocks, conflict and displacement, producing one of the largest humanitarian crises in the world today.
historicalContext.internationalLawAndAccountability: While the post-2021 context raises urgent humanitarian questions, there are also accountability dimensions connected to earlier interventions and the conduct of armed actors. Investigations, reporting and academic research have documented violations and long-term harm associated with successive periods of foreign military action, proxy support and state collapse. Although formal international accountability mechanisms have been limited or contested, documenting abuses and supporting Afghan civil society and survivors remains essential for redress and longer-term justice.

humanitarianImpact.casualties: Tens of thousands of civilian deaths directly from conflict since 2001, with indirect deaths from healthcare disruption and malnutrition substantially higher.
humanitarianImpact.affected: Over 23.7 million people (roughly half the population) require humanitarian assistance.
humanitarianImpact.foodInsecurity: Around 15.8 million people face crisis-level food insecurity at peak lean seasons.
humanitarianImpact.displaced: Over 6.3 million people internally displaced by conflict, economic pressures and climate shocks.
humanitarianImpact.refugees: More than 8.2 million Afghans are refugees or in refugee-like situations in neighbouring countries.
humanitarianImpact.healthSystemCollapsed: Thousands of health facilities face closure or severe service cuts due to funding shortfalls.
humanitarianImpact.livingInPoverty: Extreme poverty has surged since 2021, with tens of millions living in conditions of deep economic insecurity.

timeline.event: **The Great Game**: A century of imperial rivalry between the British and Russian empires reshapes Afghan frontiers and politics, with three Anglo-Afghan wars and repeated interventions that undermine indigenous political autonomy.

**Independence, Modernisation and Interference**: Afghanistan achieves formal independence in 1919 but experiences recurring foreign influence and internal contestation as attempts to centralise and modernise are mediated by regional and imperial pressures.
**The Saur Revolution**: A coup brings the PDPA to power; radical social reforms and violent repression provoke widespread unrest.
**Soviet Invasion and Occupation**: The USSR intervenes militarily to support the PDPA, triggering a decade of war that causes mass death, displacement and the destruction of infrastructure.

**US Covert Support for Mujahideen**: The CIA's Operation Cyclone funds and arms insurgent groups resisting Soviet forces; this proxy warfare has long-term consequences for militancy and state collapse.
**Taliban First Rule**: The Taliban seize Kabul after civil war and impose a repressive regime that severely curtails rights, especially for women and girls.

**US Invasion & Occupation**: Following 9/11 the US and coalition forces overthrow the Taliban and initiate a two-decade intervention that channels vast resources into security, contracting and technocratic projects that deepen dependence on foreign aid and military spending.
**US Withdrawal & Taliban Return**: The chaotic US withdrawal in August 2021 precipitates the rapid collapse of the internationally backed government and the return of the Taliban to national power.

**Economic Shock & Humanitarian Crisis**: International asset freezes, sanctions and de-risking of the financial sector, combined with climate shocks and displacement, produce a deepening humanitarian emergency with tens of millions needing assistance.

donate.description: A British humanitarian and development organisation working with deprived and excluded communities across Afghanistan.
Provides protection and assistance to refugees, returnees and internally displaced people from and within Afghanistan.
Focuses on providing education and protection for children, particularly girls, whose lives have been impacted by conflict and the economic crisis.
Delivers emergency food and nutrition support to communities across Afghanistan and is critical in preventing famine.

advocacy: Amplify Afghan civil society voices, especially women's rights activists, journalists and human-rights defenders.
Support Afghan-led organisations delivering aid and protection on the ground, and demand funding channels that enable direct, accountable transfers to local partners.
Advocate for the unfreezing or conditional, accountable release of sovereign assets to ensure civilians can access essential imports, salaries and public services.
Push for safe and legal routes for refugees and for humanitarian exemptions to sanctions that impede life-saving assistance.
Demand transparency and accountability for the costs and consequences of decades of foreign interventions and profiteering.

reading.title: Ghost Wars: The Secret History of the CIA, Afghanistan, and Bin Laden, from the Soviet Invasion to September 10, 2001
reading.description: Steve Coll's investigative account of US covert operations and their longer-term effects in Afghanistan.

reading.title: No Good Men Among the Living
reading.description: Anand Gopal's reporting on ordinary Afghans' experiences of war, occupation and the post-2001 political order.

reading.title: The Wars of Afghanistan: Messianic Terrorism, Tribal Conflicts, and the Failures of Great Powers
reading.description: A critical study of how external interventions and local dynamics have interacted to shape Afghanistan's modern history.
